message.content: We refer to a study published on the National Center for Biotechnology Information website for help. Mannitol is the most commonly used substance to measure the volume of the extracellular body fluid. It increases the osmolality of extracellular fluid and diffuses through the cell membrane slowly, so it remains mostly in the extracellular space. The other options do not have specific uses for measuring extracellular body fluid.

We refer to an article in the Journal of Clinical Medicine, which states that mannitol is commonly used to estimate extracellular fluid volume. Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that distributes itself evenly throughout the extracellular fluid compartment but has limited penetration into the intracellular compartment, making it a reliable marker for extracellular fluid volume. The other options are not commonly used for this purpose.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Mannitol is a sugar alcohol that is not normally found in the body and it distributes only in the extracellular compartment, making it useful in measuring extracellular fluid volume. Evans blue is a dye used to measure blood volume, heavy water is used to measure total body water, and radio-iodine labeled serum albumin is used to measure plasma volume.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Mannitol is an osmotic agent that can increase the extracellular space and can help measure the volume of extracellular fluid. Evans blue is a dye that can label plasma proteins and measure blood volume. Heavy water is used to measure total body water. Radio-iodine labeled serum albumin can be used to measure plasma volume.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Mannitol is commonly used to measure extracellular volume. Evans blue is used to measure plasma volume, heavy water is used to measure total body water, and radio-iodine labeled serum albumin is used to measure blood volume.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that is only distributed in the extracellular fluid space and does not cross cell membranes. Therefore, it is a useful marker for extracellular volume. The other options are not specific to extracellular fluid volume. Evans blue is used to measure plasma volume, heavy water is used to measure total body water, and radio-iodine labeled serum albumin is used to measure blood volume.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Mannitol is a sugar alcohol that is not metabolized by the body and can freely cross cell membranes. It is commonly used in clinical settings to measure extracellular fluid volume. The other options are not specific to measuring extracellular fluid volume. Evans blue is a dye used to test blood-brain barrier permeability, heavy water is used to measure total body water volume, and radio-iodine labeled serum albumin is used to measure plasma volume.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that distributes only in the extracellular space and is used to measure the volume of extracellular body fluid. Evans blue and radio-iodine labeled serum albumin are used to measure plasma volume, while heavy water is used to measure total body water.

We refer to a medical article on physiology for help. Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that is used to assess extracellular fluid volume because it does not penetrate the cell membrane and is distributed only in the extracellular fluid. Evans blue can be used to measure plasma volume, heavy water can be used to measure total body water, and radio-iodine labeled serum albumin can be used to measure plasma volume and extracellular fluid volume, but mannitol is the most appropriate option for assessing extracellular fluid volume.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Mannitol is used to measure extracellular fluid volume, as it is a freely diffusible substance that distributes only in the extracellular fluid compartment. The other options are used for different purposes, such as measuring blood volume or plasma volume.
